title: Detecting and Correcting Conservativity Principle Violations in Ontology-to-Ontology Mappings

author: Alessandro Solimando, Department of Information Engineering and Computer Science (DISI), University of Trento

segmentation: Hello everyone, good Morning I's announced that we'll be talking about the conservativity principle in ontology to ontology alignments.
So.
The general context is that as we all know.
The same application domain can be modeled by different institution.

So and in ending up with a differently and independently developed ontologies, and at some point if you want to let ontology based systems to interoperate between them, you may need to find mappings or a set of mappings that is an alignment between these independently developed ontologies and this problem is known as ontology matching problem.
But these alignments may suffer from logical violations.

In particular, free principles have been identified in literature in order to cope with this aspect, and they are the consistency principle that states that the number of incoherent classes should not increase in the line ontology with respect to the input ontologies and the conservativity principle.
That is, the one that we are coping with this work that states the new entailments should be.
Entailed by the aligned ontology among classes of the same input ontology.
In the locality principle, it's more a quality measure, not a proper logical violation.
The.
The conservativity principle is tightly coupled with the notion of.
Deductive difference or conservative extension that states that given to ontologies, Oando prime Signature Sigma in a given language.
The deductive difference is the set of axioms that can be built in the target language L using the signature Sigma that are entailed by the ontology.
Oh prime, but not by the original ontology.
Oh, the problem is.
Computationally very hard next time, hard to be precise already for a cyclic ALC and tractable algorithm exists up to now only for the L family.
So what has been done in the context of ontology matching is to propose an approximation that is targeting only atomic concepts.
So for us a conservativity principle violation is any axiom of this form where A&B are atomic concepts that is entailed by.
Sorry.
By the aligned ontology.
But it was not entailed by the input ontology that as A&B in its signature.
So in general we have that this is a violation, a isabi, but is Abby was not holding in the input ontology.
And in order to reduce the conservativity principle to the consistency one we defined an approximation of this notion as well.
That also requires that AMB are not involved in a subsumption relationship and they do not share a descendant.
So the just to give an outline.
The key ideas of our approach is to rely on this approximation of the conservativity principle and to try to.
Have scalability using modularization techniques.
To rely on a projection of the ontologies at their home propositional fragment.
So this is an approximated.
Algorithm.
And as I explained in the slide before, we partly reduce these this problem to the consistency principle problem.
So the application scenario for this worker is the European project.
Or pick where that is aimed at providing scalable ontology based that access are in the gas and oil industry.
The scenario is the following.
We have got the boot strapped ontology or one.
It is bootstrapped directly from the relational database and query formulation Ontology 02 that it's a shared by their domain expert and none of the two ontologies can be modified.
So the only way to remove these violations is to remove a subset of the alignment.

So just to sketch the algorithm, what we do is to perform a classification step of the input ontologies and aligned ontology as well to encode using the semantic index the subsumption disjointness relations in order to have a low cost.
Reasoning service on top of these indexes.
We compute the.

We detect the conservativity principle violations and we compute the horn propositional projection of the ontologies in order to be able to apply the well known darling galley algorithm in order to derive a repair for the aforementioned violations.
So let's have an example.
I don't pretend that you're going to all the details, but.
What I wanted to share with you is.
Let's say a set of mappings that are very simple and very reasonable.
And the two ontology fragments are quite simple.
But despite this situation.
And what we end up is with a set of conservativity principle violation and quite a number for such a small example.
And so for instance.

We have in the aligned ontology that the exploration borehole is a subset of exploration well, and this is an unwanted consequence for the domain experts and this is stemming from the interaction of mapping M3 and M4.
So what's the?
What's the role that this kind of violations may play in a query answering task?
Let's have an example.
Suppose that we want to ask for the wells in our database that we access using the ontology.
Using Axiom beta one and beta four, and the mappings M1M3 and M4.

But we were asking in the beginning about wells and what we.
Ends up is also data about exploration, well bore and this is of course unwanted.
If you want to get rid of these logical violations.
You encode the ontology at the horn propositional level.

So we cause an unsatisfiability by putting enough disjointness axioms.
And so among the two involved mappings we choose to remove the one with a lower confidence value that is M3 in this example.
But of course there are some violations that cannot be captured by our approximation, and so practically we wanted to.
To precisely know the amount of violations that we are not able to solve.
So in the experiments we used, we analyzed the ontology Alignment Evolution Initiative data set.
In particular, let's say we were also highly interested in having a look at the, Umm, less method is ours.
That is part of the evaluation and what we discovered is that violation rate is very high, even if these alignment are manually curated.
And so for instance, the pair of ontologies Nomad, NCI's more than 500.
Thousands of violations, so quite a lot.
We also of course tested our algorithm and we experienced.
Efficiency becausw let's say despite the size of these aligned ontology, the detection phase took only 256 seconds.
You have ever had with the aligned ontology.
You know that it's quite huge.
And also the effectivity, because in the end, even if we are relying on a set of approximate proximity algorithm, we were able to remove more than 99% of the violations.

So in practice this, despite being very simple, the approach is working quite fine and the repair time using the darling angle algorithm ranges significantly depending on the size of the ontology and can be 10 milliseconds for the conference track that is the.
The one involving small and quite small ontologies up to 22 minutes for the biggest cases in the large bio track.

Really relational database and so cannot be modified and the other one is well agreed by the domain experts.
So again, it's not something that you want to modify such an ontology.

So concluding, we experienced good efficiency and effectivity, but we also know that there can be false positives, and so in the end probably the missing ingredient now is a graphical user interface that can show to the user the violations, allow him to label which which are true positives and false positives, and repair only the subset of violations that are actually.
Violating the principle.

But this is challenging because in some cases for computed alignments we had more than 30 millions violations to show to the user and also the information in context to be visualized in order to help him is not that easy to.
To detect and for the user.
